metadata.title: Most Important IT Side Skill, Regex | by Sandro Luck (Data With Sandro) | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Most Important IT Side Skill, Regex
metadata.description: I was astounded when I first learned how to search for texts using Regex and process text data in ways unimaginable to me before. Today we can utilize its power inside Python, but it is the same in…

all_paragraphs: I was astounded when I first learned how to search for texts using Regex and process text data in ways unimaginable to me before. Today we can utilize its power inside Python, but it is the same in all other programming languages, text editors, and IDEs. We will learn the basics faster than Trump tweets!

Regex is short for Regular expression. Meaning: It is a short sequence of characters used to search or replace words in a long text. It is a minor form of a programming language that you can use to find what you need instantly. We will learn the basics using a weird little trump tweet.
Let’s load up Python and run through the basics together. First, we have to load up the module re, which handles everything regex related inside python. And let’s cut the text a little
Let’s practice some magic! We can now ask Regex to find everything until the first occurrence of a word.
This will print “[‘When you see the Drug’].”
So What Is Going On Here?

First, you may notice how we are defining our string with the prefix r’ this r indicates to python that we are about to use Regex. Also often called raw strings, this does not change the type of the string. It mostly changes how a string is interpreted. It’s not always necessary, but its best practice.
The next thing is the ‘.*Drug’ part. This consists of two ideas. First, we have the part ‘.*’ this indicates to Regex that we want every letter or symbol possible……until we see Drug.

So basically, ‘.*’ is the so-called wildcard of wildcards. Where ‘*’ indicates that we want to repeat everything before the star, 0 or more times. Where ‘.’ is the super special symbol that tells the stars that we want everything, including letters, numbers, and spaces.
This will print “[‘When you see the Drug Companies taking mass’].” Again everything from the First occurrence of “W” to the first “ss.”

Will print “[‘you ‘, ‘the ‘, ‘Companies ‘, ‘massive ‘…”. As we see, we wanted to find this time everything that stands between two spaces. I hope there is now a big question mark above your head. We put that there to make sure that Regex matches in the so-called greedy way. Greedy means here that we match only the absolute minimum until the next space. Without the “?’ and only using ‘*,’ we would match everything, including spaces so that the results would be the entire tweet (Without the last and first word)
Will print “When you see the COVID-19 Companies taking massive television ads against me, forget what they say (which is false), YOU KNOW THAT COVID-19”.

This is one of the most useful parts of Regex, you can replace everything with everything! The call re.sub(..) takes the pattern we want to replace and substitutes it with a more suiting word. We had to add the ‘flags=re.IGNORECASE’ to make sure that we match Trump’s case-insensitive tweeting style ;)
Will print “When you see the Kraken YOU KNOW THAT DRUG.” To illustrate again what we have learned.

This prints “When you KNOW DRUGS.” Ok, now we are getting into serious Regex territory. The Brackets “( )” build a matching group. This is a way to refer to something you found later on in the replace statement. We also nested the “*?” around it. So the first “( .*? )” gets us the words putting the “*” around the words matching GETS US ALL THE WORDS between “see” and “THAT.” Why do we do this? So we can refer to it later on as we can see in the replace statement ‘\\1’ takes the first word and places it into the found string. The first word in this example is “you.” This gets us to “When you KNOW DRUGS.”

These are the basic building blocks of Regex while there is a lot more you will find on your journey to Regex-Mastery these basic techniques help you understand what is possible. I hope you will now consider Regex more often. First, you may have to invest a bit of time. Once you know it, a whole new world of string manipulation will open.
If you enjoyed this article, I would be excited to connect on Twitter or LinkedIn.
Make sure to check out my YouTube channel, where I will be publishing new videos every week.
